audio_caption: The clip begins with a cheerful greeting to "insiders," followed by a male speaker introducing a special guest named James, who is involved in important captions planning. James is welcomed to the show, and he responds with gratitude for being invited.

The clip begins with a male speaker expressing enthusiasm at having someone back. He introduces the topic of community captions and emphasizes a need for transparency. He states that they're taking a hard look at whether to continue supporting the feature. Then, he asks for background on the feature, why it was done, and why they are thinking about it now. Another male speaker agrees and acknowledges the new experiment of gathering feedback. He states that creators often feel that decisions are made without input, and they are trying to take a step back to ask what they think before decisions are made. He concludes by saying they are deciding whether to continue community captions or shut them down. Finally, someone clears their throat.

The clip begins with someone stating that they need to "clarify a little bit" about a specific topic. The speaker mentions the three ways that most creators get captions or subtitles. The first way being "automatic captions", which for certain languages appear automatically on a video. The second is when creators upload the captions themselves, and the last is via a community captions feature, where anyone can suggest captions for the video.

The clip begins with a male speaker pondering whether to continue with a certain feature, questioning if the effort would be better spent elsewhere. He transitions to a thoughtful tone as a second male speaker agrees. The second speaker emphasizes their inclination to depreciate the feature, highlighting an important conversation and creator feelings about captions. He explains the idea of captions making videos accessible and questions the reasons for considering discontinuing its support. The first male speaker then responds, affirming his agreement with the framing.

The audio clip features a male speaker discussing reasons for discontinuing a service. He explains that not many creators use it, less than "one one-thousandth of a percent" of channels. He notes they discussed this with channels to understand their non-usage. He summarizes they liked the theory but faced issues such as "problems with spam," or unreliability. The speaker sounds conversational and informative.

The audio clip begins with a speaker discussing the desire to have "the most accessible product possible" and enable creators to have "the widest possible audience for their videos." The speaker then critiques a community captions feature, stating it "isn't accomplishing that goal," despite sounding good in theory. This is delivered in a conversational and critical tone. The clip features one speaker of unclear gender, though their speaking style suggests a certain level of authority or expertise.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing community captions, stating that they "only work for the biggest channels" and lead to spam and abuse issues. He notes the feature isn't used much, "only about 0.2% of watch time" and that has lead to leaning towards shutting the feature down. Another male speaker jumps in, suggesting to "just leave it alone," but the first male responds that there are "pretty significant costs to keeping it." He indicates a "responsibility to invest in the places that will have the most return." The second male speaker states that he understands and hopes others understand, stating, "if there's an angle we haven't thought about, we're going to keep an open mind."

The audio clip begins with two male speakers discussing priorities for a creator ecosystem and the future of captions. One speaker poses a question about the captions roadmap, and the other assures that they are "absolutely not getting rid of the ability for a creator to upload captions."

The clip begins with a conversational speech discussing the ongoing work on automatic captions, focusing on improving accuracy, language support, punctuation, grammar, and capitalization.
The speech emphasizes accessibility on platforms, ensuring safety for both the platform and creators. A male speaker highlights the importance of considering the trade-offs involved.
The speech transitions to discussing improvements for creators uploading their own captions, enhancing automated captions, refining them and addressing community captioning.
Finally, the clip focuses on forward-looking ideas for captions, asking about exciting aspects for consideration by the team.

A male speaker begins, excited about their work on a new captions editor, mentioning its alpha version in use by creators. He hopes to see a tighter integration between creators, autocaptions, and Google Translate, along with potential extensions to permission tools.

The clip begins with a male speaker describing feedback received from creators, mentioning that some don't use a product as intended, instead using a small team to caption videos, approving only their work. The speaker then suggests a feature request: inviting team members with specific permissions to access only the captions, which they believe would improve their workflow.

The clip begins with one male speaker wondering if James has any questions for the audience and asking them to provide feedback on how they're thinking about things. A second male speaker responds, inviting people to weigh in. The best feedback, he suggests, is information about why and how it would affect their channel if they don't think they should do this. He adds that they realize this is a tough conversation and thanks the other speaker for having it with them.

Two male speakers discuss a new format for a video. One speaker elaborates that it gives the audience some insights into product development and asks for feedback, mentioning the risk of not pleasing everyone. The tone is conversational and engaged.

The audio begins with two speakers, likely male, discussing a "bet" about being "more transparent and putting all the cards on the table." They believe this approach "might help us make a better decision based on the input." One speaker confirms "this is brand new, first time we've done something like this."

The audio clip features two male speakers. One encourages the audience to "subscribe to Creator Insider" to go "behind the curtain" and get involved in product development. He describes the content as "inside baseball stuff" and hopes some people find it helpful. He concludes by telling listeners to "keep it real" and says "we'll see you next time", thanking someone named James. A second male speaker then simply says "See ya".
